title: Public and Private Partnership for technology access (PPA) program
segmentation: Fat rich is coming from Microsoft's European Director for public private alliances, and he's been extensively involved in digital inclusion efforts.
There's been working several years on digital education content strategy.
And today he will be talking about public and private partnerships.
As means of technology access.
So I'm Mr. Mr mcfetridge.
Thank you very much.
First of all, thank you for inviting us to participate.
I've learned a lot this morning.

My background is in education and public sector policy, not specifically around E health, but one of the things that I took out of this morning is that once you get to a certain level inside governance, certain get to a certain level inside a country.
It's all at the government level.
It all requires, as my colleague before from Slovakia, said.
This idea of a public policy imperative.
Without the public policy imperative, none of these programs can exist.
In fact, I was specifically called out by 4 things that my colleagues described.
I think they're worth pointing out before I go into my session.
One is this idea of citizens health versus health care.

I think that's an excellent point because it starts to talk about ownership and two way dialogue between the citizen to patient, not just their rights, but their expectations associated with the Hill.
The second one is this idea of social and economic impact of the life years lost.
I mean the numbers are staggering, of course, and you look at it from worldwide level and the impact of that is huge.
The economic impact and benefits of addressing that or equally huge.
So I will talk about that for a moment.
This idea of a trend back to personalized access.

I think that's something that we focus very heavily on inside Microsoft across all of our programs and the idea of digital inclusion and public private partnerships that can create digital inclusion to increase that personalized access.
Absolutely critical will talk about that and then this idea of reducing inequities and empowering citizens.
You mentioned that the government mandate was the first step in all of your timeline steps there that's worth taking away.
If you don't listen anything from my presentation.
Listen to that part because that's absolutely critical to creating success.
On average.
We do about maybe you've done 150 or so public private partnerships around the world.
We've had 300 of those fail, so our ratio of failure is actually even higher than the 50%.
We learn a lot from those.
So I'll share some of those learnings from you and give you examples of some case studies that you can follow up on with the Microsoft team or with the Slovenian team here locally.
So this is sort of the initial slide and none of this is a surprise to you.
This is probably why you're in the industry and why you're visiting here today.
The importance of societal changes that require ICT innovation, number two, health and social care systems, right?
No surprise to anybody in this room.
I think that.
Thing that's interesting about this and this is where the economic impact comes in is that we look at kind of four key areas for economic benefit.
From this idea of digital inclusion in digital inclusion and social exclusion and social inclusion or themes that I'll talk about for the next 1520 minutes.
So point number one.
Obviously education and employment outcomes improve.
You give students.
You give nurses.
You give doctors you give unemployed, you give people who are under employed access to information technology, access to the Internet.

And the opportunities for economic advancement for health or well being are all raised, skipping to number 3 the efficiency savings for public service providers are obviously quite significant, and the benefits for consumers, consumers of all kinds for health care services for choice for access to services and research online that can improve their own health and well being of point #2, I think, is what we've heard about for the last couple of days here.
I'm actually very sorry, didn't hear the Danish presentation yesterday.
I've heard reference to it several times, but I thought the Montenegro presentation this morning was fantastic.

I think Austria is doing interesting things for German from Austria is here, but the idea that improve access to health information health services empowers two way dialogue with citizens I think is the cornerstone of digital inclusion that will talk about so with that.
In mind, how do you do this?
How do you create a digital inclusion consortia or public private partnership?
It's one thing if the government says as Sarkozy said yes to two weeks ago in France of 35 billion euros that I'm going to invest across our country.
Some of that will be for education that we for healthcare.
So one time splash its economic benefit, political implications, etc.
It's another to actually create sustainability, right?
These are two widely different things, so one of the things that I didn't hear earlier is the idea of non health organizations and I'll put Microsoft in that category.
Our colleagues at Cisco or Intel.

Any other partners we work with and the idea that industry is really looking over in the far right from market growth, they want to be seen as leaders and they want to be seen as growing their own citizenship, creating what we would say.
Trusted advisor kinds of relationships.
One thing to be a vendor, it's another to actually be an advisor, right?
And that goes across the industry governments.
Of course they want to build this inclusive social program.
They want to have a service level agreement to use our internal terms with their citizens.
It's much more compelling to say they actually just want to meet the expectations of their citizens, which of course are rising and rising and rising year after year.
So it's one thing inside Portugal, which I'll talk about at the end, which delivered 1.2 million PCs to all of their primary and secondary students.
Portugal has a population of 10,000,000 people, so over 10% of their country citizens received a personal computer over the course of the last two years.
It doesn't just isolate itself into education, right?
So now there's all kinds of government portals for health for welfare, for other services that now that families have access to the Internet at home through PC, the children are using it.
Of course, for education, but the family is using it for all kinds of social and economic benefits.
And of course people.
As I mentioned, they're really driving this desire for access to the Information Society.
We see that of course, more and more.
I'm sure that you're seeing that in your countries as well, so as.
You build this consortium.
What are the outcomes that you're trying to look for?
So I think from the government we covered that very clearly today.
This idea of improved perception reelection is another interesting thing to talk about.
In one of the lessons that we've learned, of course, is that ignoring the political implications of public private partnerships you do at your peril.
Many of the ones who failed have been because the distribution models the services that were being provided were perhaps 1 sided, or perhaps focused only for a particular party that was in power.
In UK, for example, there's a distribution model in place right now for 285 thousand PC's to go out to disadvantaged families.
Disadvantage families in terms of free and reduced lunch, economic and socioeconomic disadvantage.
But what they really are is there digitally and socially excluded.

So if the government did just put a 300 million pound program in place that's designed to address these students and their families with the expectation that they are able to increase the opportunity for people to access information, but they did it in an interesting way.
And this is part of the consortium they didn't just buy the computers and hand them to the students.
What they do is they issued Treasury debit cards for about 500 pounds.
They provide them out through the schools to the students who are actually eligible for free and reduced lunch and government subsidies.

And then those students get to go into whatever retail store they want near their house, so economic it stimulus, economic development, and they use that Treasury card along with an approval to buy a pre approved computer that has the right specifications that fits the governments criteria.
And then they are able to use that computer both inside school and at home.
They can choose to put in their own money if they would like and create a more interesting package.
Bioprinter do whatever they want to do.
But that kind of program is designed specifically to address.
Digital exclusion and the studies that came out of that, and I'll reference of Pricewaterhouse Coopers study.
I strongly recommend you look at.
It shows that the economic impact of giving digital inclusion to the 21% of people inside the UK who don't have access to technology or access to the Internet.
Is over 22 billion pounds.
Because the program is only 300 million, right?
So there was a 10X ROI, I think.
In Montenegro more or less if I did my math right.

I love that kind of statistics because being able to talk to our policy advisors about what it means to be able to put a public policy in place, like every single nurse should have access to a personal computer at home.
Because we know it makes them more effective at using that technology on their job.
Implies so many things.
Number one, there's a portal for them to access information.

#2 is being supported by the hospitals #3 the government is included that in budgeting and on and on and on, but those kinds of broad digital inclusion programs or what we're seeing and they transcended the deal, they transcend.
Ships that we have with governments.

This is the price Waterhouse Coopers report that I described in because it's it's such small information it will be included on the USB stick but the idea is that you can see benefits that accrue to health service providers and benefits that accrue to health service users over on the far left.
Or she's not that far right.
But the point is.
Digital inclusion.
All of the different activities the different outputs in the different outcomes that you would expect to receive from digital inclusion.
I highly recommend looking at the study.
It's a all up government study that totals the individual areas of economic benefit and social ROI.
Social return on investment from putting in digital inclusion programs.
So what have we done in countries like Portugal and the UK and Ireland and Hungary?
What are we doing in Cyprus?
What are we talking to the government about?
In Slovenia, we're talking about two governments around the world.
From Microsoft perspective, it's actually very similar to what Intel does.
It's very similar to what Oracle does is similar to what Cisco Dozen on an Apple and Google and everybody else.
What we really tried to do is we try to put the framework not in terms of what can Microsoft do, But what needs to be put in place inside the government.
Based upon our experience.
So the first thing is I mentioned before is this idea of government policies, so an example might be better health care services for all citizens, right?
What President Prime Minister doesn't want to stand up on television and make that proclamation right?
And here's how we're going to do it.
And it's a matter of creating local programs in Italy.
They have a program called One Cappuccino a day.
Does anybody heard that?
Basically, for the cost of 1 cappuccino today, you can have access to a personal computer that allows you to be a member of the Digital Society and access to Health and Education.
All kinds of benefits probably works in Italy.
It probably doesn't work in Sweden, for example, but I have seen maybe the most compelling PR statement ever and you can look at on YouTube and find it, and that is in Uruguay.
One of the Members of Parliament, Parliament to their cabinet, exact time stood up and said we have two options.
We can either build 5 kilometres of Rd.
Or we can give every student in our country a personal computer.
I'm going to guess he got reelected probably, but I mean which, which you know which one worked right?
So they gave the kids computers.
From our perspective, they gave him Linux one laptop per child computers with the hand crank and all that kind of stuff.
So it's not Microsoft win.
This is a social win, right?
I work for Microsoft, but I'm a I'm a human being.
I expect rights for healthcare.
I expect rights for my family.
I expect rights for education.

If we can set the right agenda with governments to create the right kinds of policies and industry can compete based upon their viability based upon the value they provide based upon the confidence they can.
Still in the government, being able to deliver.
And I'm happy to compete in those regards.
The challenge is when you don't have a policy, you have a one time budget.
And you have an idea that this is going to be something that we might be able to roll out over the course of the next six months before the election.
Those are difficult, difficult projects because invariably they have many contradictions associated with them.
So third in this step, and by the way, this model keeps on going all the way around around this idea of a public private partnership.
I heard again this morning.
So Montenegro presentation that they involve T-Mobile telcos.
They had the World Bank involved, they had private industry as well as national government.
That's what it takes to build these kinds of programs, and they're very difficult to do.
What it requires is that policy being the anchor.
Everything has to reflect back into that and at the same time my challenge to governments are challenged to governments is that it can't be all about squeezing the businesses.
You have to be able to create a viable business that can create sustainable and long-term growth.
It requires a commitment and a willingness to partner, requires trust, and requires a long time to build.
But those are the skills and those are the attributes.
As you're building public prior public private partnerships that you need to look for inside your program managers.
One last thing I'll say just about the telcos involved being able to include home access for programs is actually really critical.
I don't.
I can't overemphasize that.

But this idea of being able to access information wherever I am, this idea of being able to access secure information, of course, wherever I am is absolutely critical and telcos already have a good business model for that.
You can get into High Street and I think you can probably get a free laptop if you're willing to buy broadband services from the supplier for two or three years, right?
Pretty much every every city.
In Europe you can do that.
That same kind of model works when you integrate that into a public private partnership.
Designed to build digital inclusion out for families now of course connecting healthcare professionals with patients.
That's where Microsoft can come in.
We can provide the software, but it's really where the local providers can provide that the value.
So inside Portugal 1500 new jobs were created to go along with these computers.
They're all inside Portugal.
Local hardware provider actually created a new version.
I'll show you new eHealth version in a moment called Magellan.
It's a little.
Intel based laptop and they sold 450,000 of them in the country.
It was a relatively brand new innovative approach.
They exported 4 million of them outside of the country.
So GDP was raised as a result of doing this inside Portugal, right?

So these are the kinds of conversations you can be having at very senior levels inside your country, talking not just about the health and the well being benefits, but the economic impact the social ROI associated with these programs.
We have many models on this rather than go into detail on them, I'm going to recommend some some follow up afterwards if you'd like to have a conversation.
Everyone always asks what does Microsoft do?
So this is my obligatory slide.
We can do lots of things.
We've never done the same thing the same way in two countries.
You know?
Yes, we can provide discounts on software, but that's sort of the least of what we can do right.
The more compelling things are actually working together to build a partnership.
The software is what 10% of the cost of some of a solution.
It's a very small portion of it, so all the other pieces that are difficult, challenging, and we have some good experience.
So I'll give you one example.
I chose Sao Paulo, Brazil, mostly because I had a feeling nobody from Brazil would be here.
Am I correct?
OK, good good, but they're connecting 400,000 special needs patients with health care professionals and this is the theme, right?
This is a segment.
These are special needs patients who actually are interested in creating a two way dialogue with health care professionals and the Gov.

Woman has recognized that this is actually a compelling need for them, so the screenshot there is an example of the type of device that Intel is building special with the government so powerful they sell polo every 7th largest city in the world, 20,000,000 people in the basin.
It's a country basically right?

So this is a huge project, but it's only 400 thousand of these devices that are being created, but it includes in terms of the partnership, the state government, the rights for the physically disabled, right?
Obviously Microsoft, Intel the Medicine Department from the University and the project really is.
How can they create a innovative device that will be compelling for doctors and nurses and for patients to be able to access information?
So there's a device for doctors which I'm representing here.
And then there's also a notebook that.

Designed for special needs patients that they have for home use, but the goal there is that these people can contribute economically socially to the Sao Paulo region and the government believes in that and put a policy imperative in place to do so.
Next one I'll talk about briefly is in the UK, as anybody heard of the Choose and book or AHS Direct Portal.
Yeah, so it's been around for awhile.
1998 is when they first started it, the.
Is that I just want to point out on here is that the cost savings that European Commission did in 2008 restorated 100 million euros.

Euros not pounds that you see calculated that way, but they also said that 87% of the savings were attributed to the NHS and 13% actually went to the local health service users, so its benefits on both sides is more people access online benefits and online information do their scheduling do their booking online?
That ratio increases.
That's the forecast and prediction what they've seen inside that you see.
Again, there's a study down at the bottom if you'd like to get additional information on that.
The point of establishing the two way flow of information, though, is critical.
Ownership of the health process and of well being by their families by the citizens.
One point that I'll call out here and I'm sorry it's a little blurry up top is this point of social and digital exclusion.
So this is a study from the UK.
There are 760,000 families with children who are defined as socially and digitally excluded mean they don't have PC's, they don't have Internet access.
Yes, they might be able to go to cafe or a kiosk or something, but they are excluded right now.
360,000 unemployed meet that characteristic 1.5 plus million elderly.
Meet that perspective.

So the total digital exclusion when you add up everybody is about 10.2, but these three categories, families with children, unemployed and elderly, have some extra social and extra health sort of impact.
They have the average number of visits per year to their General practitioner for six, 7, etc.
The avoided cost of the consultations associated with being able to provide information online.
Is quite large, larger I would argue than the cost of perhaps providing a digital inclusion program that could last three or four years with the device.

So when governments come to me and they say or we go to governments and say, how are you going to provide access to all the wonderful things that you're doing inside the different ministries inside your different programs to provide health?
Well being education, inclusion for citizens?
It comes down to we don't have the budget to give everybody a computer, and that's not really the point.
The point is creating a program and a priority that allows for technology access.
So in Portugal what they did is they based it upon need.
If you were of extreme need, you paid 0, you have moderate need.
You paid 50 euros if you were high income, you can pay 100 euros.
So what that gave you was at your broadband access and a brand new computer and all the training and support to be able to put that in place in other countries.
We've seen the same kind of based upon need provision, and I would argue that without based upon need provision.
The projects fail.
We've learned that again and again when the government just gives them away.
What happens?

The individual doesn't value the PC, they don't value the information when they have to pay 10 euros or 10 pounds or whatever, it is at least then there's an implicit contract with that individual that allows them to take more ownership and see more value inside the technology and the tool.
So this is the points I've been covering off on Portugal.
I just list them out here because there's a couple of things I wanted to emphasize.
This happened to be an education program as I mentioned, but it had much broader impact.
Their ability to attract foreign investment was an interesting one.
Portugal is not historically known as the innovation leader of Europe.
But they actually leaped to number 3 in innovation across Europe and number one in the in the South of the EU over the course of two years.
Increase their tax revenue.
Somebody mentioned before the longer you live, the more tax you can pay.
I want to live a long time.
I don't pay a lot of tax, but I'm willing to make that trade off.
I guess the broadband growth is another interesting one.

Reason the telcos can be very important to building a sustainable model is that there's business in this for them in Portugal they took Telco spectrum funding for 3G networks and they use that to provide the initial funding for this project.
Well, the money run out and order the telcos due to the telco CEO.
We don't wanna do this anymore.
He said no.
How about we contribute money to the program?
Because we want everybody to have a PC 'cause look at our growth.
In wireless broadband, we make actually good margins.
Alright, so good sustaining model and then the jobs and the spinoff jobs etc.
A close with this slide because I think that these are the aspects for consideration that I'd like to reinforce.
Microsoft and other partners of ours and industry.
Have good examples of these.
Depending on region you're looking for, the size of the project you might be considering, but these are sort of the things that we've learned along the way.
The implications of distribution are important.
Should this be something where everybody has universal access and universal right?
And unlimited choice?
Or should it be something where the government provides guidance and can provide some directed approach towards being able to fulfill a digital inclusion public private partnership?
We would argue that that delivery model is really going to be affected by the economic expectations.
If it's a one time budget, the government can just hand them out like candy.
If it's not, you have to think very very carefully about the distribution model in the viability of that with targeting the right users.
It's of course finding a multiplier, so disadvantage students likely have unemployed or under employed parents.
Under employed or unemployed parents likely have some additional, let's say, health care needs that might be able to be addressed, right?
Look for the multiplier opportunities across all of government and then finally skipping down to the bottom.
The government goal really has to be the focal point for these projects.
We've seen again and again that if the.
The goal changes if the viability model changes and if the focus on the outcome for the citizens is not kept.
First and foremost, the projects invariably fail because it's citizen demand that drives a standard sustainability and the ongoing success of the programs.
So with that, I thank you very much.
Thank you for the invitation and look forward to talking to you soon.

There's been working several years on digital education content strategy.
And today he will be talking about public and private partnerships.
As means of technology access.

Thank you very much.
First of all, thank you for inviting us to participate.
I've learned a lot this morning.

My background is in education and public sector policy, not specifically around E health, but one of the things that I took out of this morning is that once you get to a certain level inside governance, certain get to a certain level inside a country.
It's all at the government level.
It all requires, as my colleague before from Slovakia, said.
This idea of a public policy imperative.

If we can set the right agenda with governments to create the right kinds of policies and industry can compete based upon their viability based upon the value they provide based upon the confidence they can.

And I'm happy to compete in those regards.
The challenge is when you don't have a policy, you have a one time budget.
And you have an idea that this is going to be something that we might be able to roll out over the course of the next six months before the election.
Those are difficult, difficult projects because invariably they have many contradictions associated with them.
So third in this step, and by the way, this model keeps on going all the way around around this idea of a public private partnership.
I heard again this morning.
So Montenegro presentation that they involve T-Mobile telcos.
They had the World Bank involved, they had private industry as well as national government.
That's what it takes to build these kinds of programs, and they're very difficult to do.
What it requires is that policy being the anchor.
Everything has to reflect back into that and at the same time my challenge to governments are challenged to governments is that it can't be all about squeezing the businesses.
You have to be able to create a viable business that can create sustainable and long-term growth.
It requires a commitment and a willingness to partner, requires trust, and requires a long time to build.
But those are the skills and those are the attributes.
As you're building public prior public private partnerships that you need to look for inside your program managers.

In Europe you can do that.

One point that I'll call out here and I'm sorry it's a little blurry up top is this point of social and digital exclusion.
So this is a study from the UK.
There are 760,000 families with children who are defined as socially and digitally excluded mean they don't have PC's, they don't have Internet access.
Yes, they might be able to go to cafe or a kiosk or something, but they are excluded right now.
360,000 unemployed meet that characteristic 1.5 plus million elderly.
Meet that perspective.

So the total digital exclusion when you add up everybody is about 10.2, but these three categories, families with children, unemployed and elderly, have some extra social and extra health sort of impact.
They have the average number of visits per year to their General practitioner for six, 7, etc.
The avoided cost of the consultations associated with being able to provide information online.
Is quite large, larger I would argue than the cost of perhaps providing a digital inclusion program that could last three or four years with the device.

So when governments come to me and they say or we go to governments and say, how are you going to provide access to all the wonderful things that you're doing inside the different ministries inside your different programs to provide health?
Well being education, inclusion for citizens?
It comes down to we don't have the budget to give everybody a computer, and that's not really the point.
The point is creating a program and a priority that allows for technology access.
So in Portugal what they did is they based it upon need.
If you were of extreme need, you paid 0, you have moderate need.
You paid 50 euros if you were high income, you can pay 100 euros.
So what that gave you was at your broadband access and a brand new computer and all the training and support to be able to put that in place in other countries.
We've seen the same kind of based upon need provision, and I would argue that without based upon need provision.
The projects fail.
We've learned that again and again when the government just gives them away.
What happens?

The individual doesn't value the PC, they don't value the information when they have to pay 10 euros or 10 pounds or whatever, it is at least then there's an implicit contract with that individual that allows them to take more ownership and see more value inside the technology and the tool.

Increase their tax revenue.

The implications of distribution are important.
Should this be something where everybody has universal access and universal right?
And unlimited choice?
Or should it be something where the government provides guidance and can provide some directed approach towards being able to fulfill a digital inclusion public private partnership?
We would argue that that delivery model is really going to be affected by the economic expectations.
If it's a one time budget, the government can just hand them out like candy.
If it's not, you have to think very very carefully about the distribution model in the viability of that with targeting the right users.
It's of course finding a multiplier, so disadvantage students likely have unemployed or under employed parents.
Under employed or unemployed parents likely have some additional, let's say, health care needs that might be able to be addressed, right?
Look for the multiplier opportunities across all of government and then finally skipping down to the bottom.
The government goal really has to be the focal point for these projects.
We've seen again and again that if the.
The goal changes if the viability model changes and if the focus on the outcome for the citizens is not kept.
First and foremost, the projects invariably fail because it's citizen demand that drives a standard sustainability and the ongoing success of the programs.
So with that, I thank you very much.
